Text: Thank you.
I'm looking forward to your involvement at the Neuroscience Center,
-Chief Min. -Goodness.
Yes. I'm looking forward to it, too.
It's only been a few days, but I can see you have a great system
and talented medical staff here.
I should thank you for allowing me to join.
Professor Chae, I'm looking forward to working with you.
Why don't we all have a meal together? The cafeteria serves good food.
-Yes, sir. -Yes, sir.
Don't be so formal. You can talk to me casually.
Okay.
Professor Min looks much better in person than on TV.
He's on a lot of TV shows,
but he performs all of his surgeries himself.
I want you to take Gong Hyeong-u's surgery.
He's not in critical condition. But this surgery is tricky.
Reporters have their eyes on us,
so his surgery must go well, no matter what.
We can use this surgery to get your name out there.
My surgery schedule for next week is full. I don't have time for it.
Come on.
Min-sik, I heard you have a third baby on the way.
What? How did you know?
I heard you guys talking.
You should go home.
I can handle your emergency calls. I can take two or three calls a month.
-Thank you. It's a nice gesture. -It's not just a gesture.
You're breaking my heart.
Thank you.
By the way, how much longer are they going to film us?
Gosh, working as a TV director must be so hard.
Goodness, nothing is easy in this world.
Sir.
You should just eat comfortably.
I won't go anywhere.
I'll do everything you ask. Just enjoy your meal.
Thank you.
Dr. Yong.
Han Seung-hyeok needs a lumbar drain.
Have you done it?
Who?
Han Seung-hyeok in Room 7104.
Isn't that Professor Min Gi-jun's patient?
Yes.
This is Park Jeong-su. I took a look at his CT angiography scan this morning.
I saw an unruptured cerebral aneurysm, so he was admitted today.
His surgery is scheduled next week.
You look more handsome in the patient gown.
Dr. Min, this surgery isn't difficult, is it?
I have performed this surgery hundreds of times.
You don't have to worry.
Where's the location of his aneurysm?
The right paraclinoid aneurysm is on the cerebral artery.
-But its neck seemed narrow. -I see.
There won't be any problems. It's a simple surgery.
Do you have a girlfriend?
Yes.
Wait, no.
What? Do you think I'd be against you having a girlfriend?
Gosh, he's making me look bad.
-All right, then. -Thank you, Doctor.
Sure.
Hello. How do you feel today?
Whatever.
What? What are you going to do?
-Is that so? -They only ran a blood test
and gave him an IV drip.
And no one came to check on him!
We still haven't heard about his surgery date.
No one gave us an update.
Do you just want him to die? Is that it?
I am truly sorry.
I believe my resident missed it as he was busy.
I will apologize on his behalf.
I am very sorry.
Who's in charge?
Should I just do it myself?
Han Seung-hyeok really needs to get a lumbar drain today.
You can't just do it yourself.
Professor Min told you to check everything with him.
Don't you remember the colossal disaster last week?
Professor Min should at least give you orders.
He didn't give any orders after the patient got admitted.
He seems nice in front of patients, but he doesn't care about them at all.
Seok-min, I moved up Lee Myeong-gi's surgery.
Get his guardian's consent.
Okay.
It's not that urgent. Finish your ramyeon and take a breather.
I'm done.
Take your time.
You!
How can you be eating right now?
How can you eat now?
Why didn't you do a lumbar drain for Han Seung-hyeok?
-Why didn't you do it? -Sir.
Do you call yourself a doctor?
How can you call yourself a doctor?
What if the hydrocephalus gets worse and puts him in danger?
Will you take responsibility for that? Will you?
You didn't give me any orders. Why are you blaming me?
Are you out of your mind?
How dare you talk back to me?
Hey.
Hey.
You call yourself a chief resident?
You can't even make a judgment call. You shouldn't be a chief resident.
Seriously?
Look at you.
Are you glaring at me?
Stop glaring.
Stop glaring at me, you bastard!
Stop glaring!
Lastly, the complications.
One percent of patients experience altered consciousness,
convulsion, dyskinesia, and so on. Sequelae are infectious diseases,
encephalitis, meningitis, and brain abscess. Any questions?
I doubt you have any.
All right, then.
Okay.
Lastly, due to the lack of oxygen in the organs,
one percent of patients suffer organ failure, brain damage, and--
"Brain damage"?
How did you not know Mother was this sick?
Doctor, is my mom's surgery that serious?
No, they're just the possibilities.
I'm only informing you of the possibilities.
Her heart muscles may be damaged during the surgery.
In severe cases, she may die.
"Die"?
She was fine just a few minutes ago.
I'm not saying that she will die.
I'm saying that could happen.
Oh, Mom.
What if Mom dies during the surgery?
I feel so bad for her!
I won't be able to live! I'm going to miss her so much!
I can't live without her.
Mom. You!
Mom!
Poor Mom!
Excuse me. She's still alive.
Mom.
Mom.
Mom.
Did you just get here? Are you on the night shift again?
-No, I'm not. -Are you going home now?
I have the morning shift.
Then why are you here at seven?
This is when my shift starts.
-It's night. -It's morning.
What?
YULJE MEDICAL CENTER
Tell me about the patient.
He had a stomachache and was constipated, so I performed an enema. He's fine now.
I'm sorry, sir.
My intern was so scared that they called you directly.
I'm sorry.
No, that's okay.
You must have been scared, too.
You were scared, weren't you?
This happens to kids often, so you don't need to worry too much.
A lot of kids around Jeong-hu's age come to the ER because of constipation.
-Isn't he your first son? -Yes.
Moms get scared for their first children and come to the ER a lot.
Moms with second or third children are like experts.
They come here, ask for the meds, chat a little, and leave.
Really?
I was so scared that something would happen to my son.
My gosh, I still have a long way to go as a mother.
Even experienced mothers get scared for their first children.
It's natural to be scared. Don't beat yourself up.
It looks like he fell asleep.
We should let him sleep. Do you want to get some coffee?
-Sounds great. -Let's go.
Is the café open?
Professor Lee, I noticed that the date for my returning flight is next week,
not this week.
I'm grateful that you paid for my flight.
But what about U-ju? Who will watch U-ju?
U-ju? My parents are coming this afternoon.
They will watch him for me. You have nothing to worry about.
Okay. Go sightseeing with your daughter.
You know, China is a big country.
U-ju, that's spicy.
It's really spicy.
You should eat your soup. Eat your food.
Okay. Bye.
Hi, Mom.
Why would I go there with Professor Jang?
Gosh. I can't go there for a reason.
I broke up with him.
I broke up with Professor Jang.
What? Why?
He cheated on me.
He cheated on...
That jerk, Professor Jang, cheated on me.
Last week, when I was tired after surgery,
he came to my office himself and confessed everything.
He said he was seeing someone else.
My gosh. I'm not in my 20s. Of course, I'm fine.
I'm really busy these days. Maybe it's better this way.
I can live without him. Or I can get a new boyfriend.
Mom, I'm going into surgery. Bye.
You startled me.
Are you trying to look funny?
That, too.
Stay ten steps away from me.
It's embarrassing to be seen with you.
Did Professor Jang cheat on you?
Did you hear that?
If I didn't, I should go to an ENT doctor.
Hey, by the way,
your vocalization is really nice.
You have perfect pitch.
I'm the band's vocalist for a reason.
That... Gosh.
A cold cup of iced Americano, please.
Iced Americano is already cold.
-They mean the same thing. -Yes, they do. So just pick one.
You pay for this. Bye.
Gosh, that rude jerk.
I'm sorry.
A cold cup of iced Americano and that jerk's chocolate milk.
And the scone, too.
I came to the hospital, so I could live.
Did you think I came here to die?
You know what? When someone is in pain, you should give them painkillers
or check if everything's okay with the surgical wound.
You just come here once or twice a day. Is that all you do?
Is that all?
Excuse me. When you scream like this,
you make other patients uncomfortable.
I'm in pain! I said I'm in severe pain!
If a patient is in so much pain, shouldn't you do something about it?
Dr. Chae.
They need to dress the wound three times a day.
Dressing it twice won't disinfect the wound enough.
I'll tell them to take better care of you. Please don't be upset.
If you say so.
It would've been great if you'd done a better job from the start.
Do you have urination problems?
No. It's all good.
I pee just the right amount.
Okay, then.
Discharge the patient.
Pardon?
Didn't you hear her voice just now?
She's full of energy.
She's all better now. Let's discharge her.
Okay.
The patient's INR is off the charts! What were you doing?
I'm sorry.
Is that all?
Didn't I tell you to check his INR
and give him two FFPs if his INR went over two?
I even told you the number of FFPs because you can't do that yourself.
You should've followed my orders.
Doctor.
I came here because my heart is not well.
But my heart is about to explode right now.
I'm sorry.
Do your job, please.
Doctor, are you all right?
Yes.
Is there anything else?
No. I'm fine.
I'm sorry. You got scolded because of me.
My gosh, I got scolded because I messed up.
Sorry?
I'll come back after my meal.
Is Dr. Yong here?
What brings you all the way to NS, Jae-hak?
Say hello to the chief resident for CS. It's Dr. Do Jae-hak.
-Hello. -Hello.
-Are these the med students? -Yes. Guys, sit down.
-Okay. -Okay.
They are med students. Our department has them this week.
He looks pretty old, doesn't he?
He started college before some professors.
No, I didn't.
I took the CSAT four times and the bar exam six times.
Memorize that. Let's go eat.
Eat? What's that?
I must attend the conference for Gong Hyeong-u's surgery.
I know him. The good Samaritan, Gong Hyeong-u.
He was a subway homeless guy.
He's a hero who saved a pregnant lady from the tracks.
I don't get why Chief Min is suddenly leading this surgery.
This patient needs transsphenoidal surgery.
Dr. Chae is the specialist for it. How could he steal that?
An endoscope is inserted into the nose.
I gathered all of his data, too.
It will be perfect if I do this with Dr. Chae.
My gosh. Aren't you going to eat?
I told you I have a conference.
Dr. Heo Seon-bin. Dr. Ahn Chi-hong.
They are three-year residents.
-Hello. -Hello.
I've got a question for you. Are you guys a thing, too?
-No, we are not. -We are not a thing, either.
Why are you always together? Captain Ahn is older than you.
He's from the military academy. People are fascinating.
We're close. We went to the same med school.
But your genders...
-My gosh. He's so old-fashioned. -Oh, Father.
That's what I should say.
What am I going to do with this surgery?
Dr. Heo, take the med students with you.
Dr. Ahn, come with me to the conference.
Okay.
It's a large pituitary tumor.
I don't think I can remove the tumor completely through the TSA.
So I'll take the pterional approach to resect the tumor.
If you do, there will be a lot of bleeding.
Won't that cause a brain injury?
It's an unusually big tumor.
It's deeply expanded into the suprasellar region.
It's better if I take the pterional approach.
But I still believe the TSA is a better approach.
He'll need radiation therapy later,
but given that he has diabetes and his wounds will heal slowly,
performing a craniotomy is too much.
We must remove the tumor completely.
The first thing the press asks will be the result of the surgery.
If we say some of the tumor remains and he might undergo radiation therapy,
what do you think those reporters will write?
It will only ruin the hospital's reputation.
Saving the patient and removing the tumor completely is important.
But if you take that approach,
his optic nerves or his pituitary stalk might be damaged.
I don't think you guys have much experience with this surgery.
I've performed this surgery hundreds of times.
The quality of his life is important,
but seeing the tumor myself
and removing it completely will be much better for him.
I've had a very low percentage of sequelae among my patients.
Their recoveries weren't that bad.
It's got to be more than a low chance of suffering from sequelae.
Even if our reputation gets ruined for a while,
the patient's quality of life must be taken into account.
Wait here. I'm going to the bank.
Hey, Old-timer.
Share your wisdom with the med students. You've lived twice as long as them.
"Old-timer"? I'm still in my 30s.
But you turn 40 next year.
All right. First off, what are your names?
My name is Jang Hong-do.
I bet you were good at ssireum at your school.
What do you do for fun? Calligraphy?
No, I play the guitar. I'm in a band at my church.
Not a traditional instrument?
Sorry.
What's your name?
It's Yun-bok.
Don't joke around.
You informed Dr. Chae, right?
Her phone was off, so I sent a text.
Okay. She has a lecture today.
She will respond soon.
-Does she give lectures? -Yes.
She teaches and does a lot of surgery.
And she checks residents' papers thoroughly.
And she attends symposiums. She goes hiking and camping on weekends.
But she still manages to come to work at 7 a.m. She's never late.
Is that even possible?
That's why her nickname is Ghost. I gave her that nickname.
She's in the lobby. She's coming with Ms. Hwang.
See?
There's no other explanation of how she can do everything unless she's a ghost.
Let's go in.
You're known as the Ghost. And yet, your shoes are worn out.
-I'm the Ghost? -Yes, that's your nickname.
-Why is that? -Because you can't be human.
It's post-op day seven for Kim Ju-chan. How is he?
His wound is clean. We can take his stitches out.
By the way, your birthday is next week.
I'll buy you a pair of shoes.
This pair can last me ten more years.
It's been about ten years since I first saw them.
You got them when you were a resident.
You should bid farewell to your shoes.
Who was it?
Who nicknamed me?
Yong Seok-min did.
Got it.
My gosh.
You still have a long way to go,
but make sure you choose GS for your field when you become residents.
Don't say, "You mean the GS convenience store?"
It's not the GS home-shopping network either.
I see. You mean, general surgery?
That's right.
I know there aren't a lot of residents for other fields either.
But there are only a handful of GS residents in Korea.
You know what?
There has been a new dynamic to this.
Listen up, Jang-hwa and Hong-ryeon.
Our names are Hong-do and Yun-bok.
Okay. Hong-do and Yun-bok. Listen carefully.
Here in our hospital, there are 13 general surgeons.
But there is only one resident.
Dr. Jang Gyeo-ul, what are you doing?
She's like the only daughter of 13 dads.
Then, who do you think has the upper hand?
Guys, general surgery isn't so bad.
Dr. Jang, why did you come to work so early?
I told you to take today off.
She prepared the materials for a colorectal surgery meeting.
Don't talk to her. She's busy.
And get lost.
Go.
My goodness. Dr. Jang, have you eaten?
I had pot noodles here earlier.
Pot noodles?
That's not real food. Come on.
Let's go. I'll buy you a meal. Come.
If you collapse, General Surgery will collapse, too. Come.
-I'm fine. -Really?
You were reading Lee Yong-chan's chart.
This patient will get a liver transplant tomorrow morning.
Liver transplant. And I'm leading the surgery.
Do you want to join me?
He's an HCC patient.
Dr. Jang, I'm doing my rounds.
Can you come with me?
-No, she can't. No. -Hey, hold on.
You'll join me, right?
I still can't turn my head because I had to do surgery alone yesterday.
I can do it if it's in the morning.
Really?
Really?
There you are, Dr. Jang.
Can you help me with my breast cancer surgery tomorrow morning?
Yes, I will.
Hey, you.
Dr. Lee Ik-jun.
Hello, sir.
You know what?
How are you such a great dancer? How?
I have never seen anyone who's as good at singing and dancing as you
and who knows how to have fun as much as you.
I'm flattered, sir.
I'll see you at the next gathering.
-Okay. -Have a good day.
Dr. Jang, that means that you won't be joining me tomorrow morning, right?
I'm sorry.
I'll disinfect everything tomorrow,
open the patient up, and close him up by myself.
But next time,
please...
Pick me, pick me, pick me up
-Pick me, pick me, pick me up -Yes?
I'll be right there.
-Where? Eat the sausage. -It's the ER.
Should I call Jeong-won? I heard he's not busy.
It was a personal call to me.
Hello, ma'am.
What? Okay. I'll be there.
Don't worry. Just go.
I'll take care of it. Yes.
That's the Blood Collection Room, CT Scan Room,
X-Ray Room and MRI Room.
If you go straight, there's the PET Scan Room.
You've heard of PET, right?
PET? Like a plastic bottle?
Positron emission tomography?
What is that used for?
I don't know that much yet.
We just got into med school.
You guys are soulmates, aren't you?
-Yes. -I knew it.
Dr. Heo, will we be going to the operating rooms?
Someday.
Hui-su, I saw your Instagram post. You had a soufflé pancake yesterday.
-Was that any good? -Totally.
I went to the cafe at 3 p.m. after work. I didn't have to wait.
You should go and try it, too.
If only I had time.
Can you come with me, then?
Actually, I should treat you to a meal for looking after my interns.
You always treat me. It's on me next time.
Dr. Jang, have some cookies.
No, I don't like sweets.
I see. Okay.
How old is the patient?
He's a seven-year-old and was in a traffic accident.
And he shows signs of stupor.
That's why I called the GS.
I see.
Hello.
Okay.
It will take 20 more minutes.
-Then, I'll come back after my meal. -Okay.
Guys, this isn't free. It's coming out of my paycheck.
We had pot noodles just now.
Thank you for the meal.
Let's go.
Sir, a lot of sausages, please.
-Are you a resident? -Pardon?
-Yes. -Okay. Then, you can have three sausages.
She told me not to give more than two,
but I gave you three since you're a resident. Next.
-Are you an intern? -No, I'm a med student.
My gosh. I'll give you five sausages.
Here.
There you go.
-You, too? -Yes.
Okay. Here. There you go.
What are you doing here?
You're a professor.
You get one sausage.
That way, I can even out the sausages.
I gave a lot of sausages to the people in front of you.
The higher your position is, the fewer sausages you get.
Don't stand there. Keep moving.
The cafeteria lady and I are best friends.
Her son suddenly ended up at the police station.
I'm wearing gloves and a mask.
Give me one more.
-Just one more. -Get lost. Next.
Okay.
Seriously?
Darn it.
Gosh.
Here.
This way, I can balance supply and demand.
I gave a lot of sausages to the people in front of you.
You should make a small sacrifice, sir.
Next.
Hi.
You know how much I care, right?
Thank you.
Wait.
They prepare everything
from breakfast, lunch, dinner, late-night snacks to boxed meals during surgery.
Even boxed meals?
They send meal boxes upstairs.
We can't come down to eat during surgery.
After eating this meal, will we go to the operating rooms?
I don't know.
Okay.
A seven-year-old boy from a traffic accident.
He was out with his mom. He was trying to pick up a toy on the road
when a speeding truck crashed into him. His BP is 60/40.
I think his pelvis and chest bone are broken.
Ju-hwan.
I see intraperitoneal bleeding and thoracic injury.
From the X-ray, he has a cervical spine injury.
And it seems he has a pelvic fracture, too.
What should we do?
What do you mean? We should try to save him.
Get a CT scan now.
He might have a brain injury, so call Dr. Chae.
Okay.
Where's Dr. Ahn Jeong-won?
He was working outside today, but he's almost here.
This will be a tough case even with Jeong-won's help. Goodness.
He's losing consciousness.
And we can't get his pulse, and his breathing is weak.
We only checked his ultrasound and X-ray scan.
He has hemoperitoneum,
cervical spine injury, and a pelvic fracture.
We'll know more once we take his brain CT.
There's a high chance that his brain might be swelling as well.
We can operate, but even if we do,
it may be hard for him to regain consciousness.
What are you doing? Go.
His guardian must be waiting. Go talk to her now.
Yes, Doctor.
We have our conference rooms here.
When a patient needs surgery, the surgeon doesn't make all the decisions.
All the professors in the department gather,
discuss the best approach for the patient,
and advise each other.
Let's see if this room is open.
They are cute.
I used to be young like them.
I'm sorry.
Anyway, we have our precious med students.
Let's listen to why they applied to med school.
What's wrong with him? Just let them go.
Right? You don't like that, either.
-Pardon? -I'm sorry.
I won't talk to you.
Both of my parents are doctors, so I didn't have much choice--
Hey, Seon-bin. We're not interested in your story.
Let's start with you, first.
Why did you decide to study medicine?
Well...
my mother had major surgery ten years ago.
I was moved by the devoted doctor who treated my mom.
So I decided to study medicine.
Gosh, that's great.
Next.
Well...
my mother had major surgery ten years ago.
I was moved by her passionate doctor--
She already said that.
Your friend just said that.
I'm sorry. We'll get going now.
-Let's go. -Bye.
Bye.
Bye.
-Let's go that way. -Thank you.
TELL THEM YOU'LL DO IT, PROFESSOR
Thank you.
Yes. This is Chae Song-hwa speaking.
I called you at the perfect time, right?
Yes. Nicely done.
Who is it? Come in.
You should volunteer to do it.
Unbelievable.
Do you think doing surgery is like booking a hotel room?
Changing the lead surgeon isn't that simple.
Are you going to watch the patient die?
Hey!
Professor Min said he won't do a craniotomy. He'll do the TSA.
What's the problem here?
He's only performed a TSA once in his career.
And his fellow doctor
did most of the work while he just stood in the OR.
The tumor expanded into the suprasellar region.
Executing the TSA will be especially difficult for this case.
I'm sure he can handle it.
At his previous hospital, his fellow doctor
did the TSA for him. But what about us?
We have you. You can assist him.
I don't know anything!
You startled me. Keep your voice down.
Professor Chae.
Will you let Professor Min operate on Gong Hyeong-u?
That's not right. We can't do that to a patient.
You should talk to the hospital director.
Tell him you'll do it.
Isn't that in two days?
I have skull base tumor surgery tomorrow afternoon.
It won't have ended by then.
I just don't have time for it.
You can ask the anesthesiologist to buy you some time.
I'll set up everything.
I don't know. Gosh, I'm getting a headache.
Jun-wan, do you have anything for headaches?
You're a neurosurgeon. Don't you have anything?
Let's go to my office.
Professor Chae. Please.
-Professor Chae. -Stop it.
That's enough whining.
-What did I just say? -You saw Professor Jang with his junior.
-You knew it, didn't you? -It was a coincidence.
-Hey. -It's a day or two before he came clean.
I was going to tell you.
You should've told me right away.
I can't assume anything about relationships.
If you see something, just tell me as it is.
Your concern doesn't matter.
Hey, it's not that easy to do. You think you could've told me?
Yes. I would tell you right away.
I would tell you your girlfriend was cheating on you the second I saw it.
-What is it? -It's time for your outpatients.
-I don't have outpatients today. -I was talking to Professor Chae.
Right.
We're not done.
Dr. Ahn Chi-hong from NS was waiting by the door.
Okay.
Good. This is the best thing you've done this year.
It's highly likely that he's having hemorrhagic shock.
Then, what should we do?
His pulse is weak.
We believe he may have a thoracic and brain injury.
We took him up for CT.
But we're not sure if he will last.
There's a slim chance we can save him.
There's no hope for him.
Doctor, please save Ju-hwan.
If he's gone,
I won't be able to live.
Did you perform CPR?
Pardon?
Did you do chest compressions?
No.
He could have lived if you had done that.
-What? -Dr. Jang.
-Yes? -A word, please.
I'm Professor Ahn from Pediatric Surgery.
It is true that things aren't good for your son,
but we will do everything we can to save him.
I'll talk to you once we get the CT scan.
Ma'am, it's too early to be sure about anything.
Dr. Jang, how long have you been a resident?
-Three years. -Is that how you talk to guardians?
He could've lived if she did CPR?
How could you say that?
Did you think about how guilty she would feel for the rest of her life?
And how can you be certain if he has no hope or a slim chance?
I've observed him since he got here.
I only told her the facts
after reading his chart and observing his condition.
But what I told her is true.
He indeed has a slim chance.
I told her the truth because I believed she needed to know her son's condition.
Telling her that she should have performed CPR...
It was my mistake. I am sorry.
What are you doing here?
Come out. We need this bed.
How's the kid? Did you call Song-hwa?
I don't have to.
What?
There's no brain damage from the CT scan.
We can save him if we focus on stopping the bleeding.
My gosh. That was a close one.
I need to treat a patient with a stomachache.
And I'm taking Dr. Bae Jun-hui.
Dr. Jang, talk to the guardian for me.
Dr. Jang.
Do you know why doctors only give vague answers such as "We can't be sure yet,"
"We don't know yet,"
and "We need to observe a bit more"?
Doctors must take responsibility for their words.
So we must be careful with our words.
There's only one thing we, doctors, can tell our patients with certainty.
"We will do our best."
That's the only thing.
Go.
His mother will be so happy to hear that.
Okay. Bye.
